docs.snippet: On March 7, New Yorkers with an outsize share of local pride can head to Alice Tully Hall for the city's first-ever official Oscar-watching party....
docs.lead_paragraph: Forget the Kodak Theater. On March 7, New Yorkers with an outsize share of local pride - which is to say, most of us - can head to Alice Tully Hall for the city's first-ever official Oscar-watching party. The event, organized by NYC & Company, the tourism bureau, will include a cocktail reception and music by the Juilliard Jazz Ensemble, which will play songs from Oscar-winning films. Tickets are $150 and $225 and available here.
docs.abstract: On March 7, New Yorkers with an outsize share of local pride can head to Alice Tully Hall for the city's first-ever official Oscar-watching party.

docs.snippet: With their hair rolled and fluffed, their lips glossy and eyes smoldering in the direction of the photographers (egad!), the models at Oscar de la Renta today hinted of espionage....
docs.lead_paragraph: With their hair rolled and fluffed, their lips glossy and eyes smoldering in the direction of the photographers (egad!), the models at Oscar de la Renta today hinted of espionage. Or maybe a dangerous affair! O.K., how about lunch at La Grenouille. Mr. de la Renta was very much in a luxe-glam zone, now with a leaner silhouette than recent seasons, below-the-knee skirts in tweed embroidered at the hem and finished with a nutria band, and a palette that included magenta, lapis blue and emerald paired with black. Evening clothes were predominantly in black, silvery gray and champagne.
docs.abstract: With their hair rolled and fluffed, their lips glossy and eyes smoldering in the direction of the photographers (egad!), the models at Oscar de la Renta today hinted of espionage.
